title-group.article-title: β-catenin is Required in Odontoblasts for Tooth Root Formation

article-meta.aff: 1Cluster for Craniofacial Development and Regeneration Research, Institute of Oral Biosciences, Chonbuk National University School of Dentistry, Jeonju 561-756, South Korea
2Genetic Laboratory of Development and Disease, Institute of Biotechnology, China
3Division of Developmental Biology, Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, OH, USA

fn.p: authors contributing equally to this work

permissions.copyright-statement: © International & American Associations for Dental Research 2013
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: The tooth root is an important part of the tooth that works together with the surrounding periodontium to maintain the tooth in the alveolar socket. The root develops after crown morphogenesis. While the molecular and cellular mechanisms of early tooth development and crown morphogenesis have been extensively studied, little is known about the molecular mechanisms controlling tooth root formation. Here, we show that β-catenin is strongly expressed in odontoblast-lineage cells and is required for root formation. Tissue-specific inactivation of β-catenin in developing odontoblasts produced molars lacking roots and aberrantly thin incisors. At the beginning of root formation in the mutant molars, the cervical loop epithelium extended apically to form Hertwig’s epithelial root sheath (HERS), but root odontoblast differentiation was disrupted and followed by the loss of some HERS inner layer cells. However, the outer layer of the HERS extended without the root, and the mutant molars finally erupted. The periodontal tissues extensively invaded the dental pulp. These results indicate that there is a cell-autonomous requirement for Wnt/β-catenin signaling in the dental mesenchyme for root formation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Tooth roots develop following crown formation. During early root morphogenesis, the cervical loop epithelium extends and forms the Hertwig’s epithelial root sheath (HERS). Mesenchymal cells in the dental papilla differentiate into pre-odontoblasts inside the HERS and further differentiate into odontoblasts to produce root dentin (Thomas, 1995).

The Wnt family of proteins plays an important role in morphogenesis and cellular differentiation in many tissues (Logan and Nusse, 2004). The canonical Wnt signaling pathway involves the stabilization and nuclear accumulation of β-catenin, which activates the expression of Wnt target genes (Reya and Clevers, 2005). It is well known that Wnt/β-catenin signaling plays multiple roles in various stages of tooth morphogenesis (Liu and Millar, 2010). However, little is known about the involvement of Wnt/β-catenin signaling in odontoblast differentiation. During dentin formation, Wnt10a is expressed in odontoblast-lineage cells, and Axin2 is also expressed in developing odontoblasts and dental pulp cells (Yamashiro et al., 2007; Lohi et al., 2010). In addition, Dkk1, an inhibitor of Wnt signaling, is strongly expressed in pre-odontoblasts, but is decreased in secretory odontoblasts (Fjeld et al., 2005). Moreover, it was recently reported that Lef-1 overexpression accelerates odontoblast differentiation of dental pulp cells, and constitutive β-catenin stabilization in the dental mesenchyme can lead to excessive dentin formation (Yokose and Naka, 2010; Kim et al., 2011). These reports strongly suggest that modulation of Wnt/β-catenin signaling may play an important role in odontoblast differentiation.

During root formation, numerous growth factors and transcription factors, such as Shh, BMP, and Msx, are extensively expressed in the dental epithelium and mesenchyme (Yamashiro et al., 2003; Nakatomi et al., 2006). Recently, TGF-β and Shh signaling have been implicated in tooth root development (Huang et al., 2009). However, the molecular mechanisms that regulate odontoblast differentiation for root formation remain unclear. In addition, it is not known whether Wnt signaling in the dental mesenchyme is involved in root formation. Here, we analyzed mice with tissue-specific inactivation of β-catenin, an obligatory transducer of canonical Wnt signaling, in developing odontoblasts to directly investigate the role of Wnt/β-catenin signaling in root formation.

sec.title: Mouse Strains and Genotyping
sec.p: All experimental procedures were approved by the Animal Welfare Committee of the Chonbuk National University. β-catenin-floxed allele mice (Brault et al., 2001) and R26R reporter mice (Soriano, 1999) were purchased from Jackson Laboratory (Bar Harbor, ME, USA). Osteocalcin-Cre (OC-Cre) mice were generated with the 1.3-kb mouse osteocalcin promoter as described previously (Tan et al., 2007). To generate OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice, we crossed OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/+ mice with Ctnnb1CO/CO mice. The offspring were genotyped by polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) analysis with previously described primers (Brault et al., 2001; Gao et al., 2009). For analysis of Cre activity in OC-Cre mice, OC-Cre mice were crossed with R26R mice, and the mandibles of double-transgenic mice were processed for X-gal staining as described previously (Chen et al., 2009; Kim et al., 2011).

sec.title: Histology, Immunohistochemistry, and in situ Hybridization
sec.p: For histological analysis, mice were sacrificed, and the mandibles were carefully dissected. The tissues were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) and decalcified in 10% EDTA solutions for 2 to 4 wks at 4°C. The decalcified tissues were dehydrated through a graded ethanol series, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned at 5-µm thickness. Slides were stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

For immunostaining, sections were treated with 3% hydrogen peroxide and incubated with rabbit polyclonal antibodies against β-catenin (1:250; Thermo Scientific, Fremont, CA, USA), ALPL (1:50; Protein Tech, Chicago, IL, USA), cytokeratin 14 (1:1,000; Covance, Berkeley, CA, USA), Phex (1:50; Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA), periostin (1:600; Abcam, Cambridge, UK), Dmp1 (1:750; Takara Bio Inc., Shiga, Japan), and Axin2 (1:300, Abcam). Histostain Plus rabbit primary (DAB) kit (Zymed Laboratories, San Francisco, CA, USA) was used according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

In situ hybridization of tissue sections was performed as described previously (Baek et al., 2011). We prepared digoxigenin-labeled probes for Dsp (Qin et al., 2003) and osteocalcin (kindly provided by Dr. J.E. Kim).

sec.title: Cell Proliferation Assay
sec.p: For detection of cell proliferation in the developing roots, 5′-bromo-2′deoxyuridine (BrdU) labeling reagent (45 µg/g body weight; Roche, Indianapolis, IN, USA) was injected intraperitoneally into eight-day-old OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/+ (control) and OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO (mutant) mice. Two hrs after injection, mice were dissected, and the mandibles were fixed with Carnoy’s fixatives at 4°C overnight, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned in the coronal plane for immunodetection with the BrdU labeling and detection kit (Roche) as described previously (Baek et al., 2011).

sec.title: Microcomputerized Tomography
sec.p: Mandibles were dissected from four-week-old control or mutant mice, bisected at the symphysis, and fixed in 4% PFA. The mandibles were scanned by means of a desktop scanner (1076 Skyscan Micro-CT, Skyscan, Kontich, Belgium) and subsequently reconstructed and analyzed with CTscan software (Skyscan).

sec.title: Tooth Isolation
sec.p: Skin and muscles were clipped away from the dissected mandibles of four-week-old control or mutant mice. The mandibles were then incubated in 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 0.5% SDS, and 0.2 mg proteinase K/mL at 55°C for 1 hr. After a brief wash in water, incisors and molars were extracted and cleared in 1% KOH for 3 days.

sec.title: β-catenin Expression in Odontoblast-lineage Cells during Root Formation
sec.p: In the developing root of the mouse mandibular first molar at P14, odontoblast-lineage cells were classified as odontoblasts, differentiating odontoblasts, or pre-odontoblasts, according to their status of differentiation (Fig. 1A). Immunohistochemical experiments revealed that Phex, a phosphate-regulating endopeptidase, was exclusively localized in odontoblasts (Fig. 1B). ALPL, a tissue-non-specific alkaline phosphatase, was localized in differentiating odontoblasts and odontoblasts, but not pre-odontoblasts (Fig. 1C). In contrast, β-catenin was observed in all odontoblast-lineage cells in the root as well as in HERS cells and the periodontium (Fig. 1D). However, ALPL was not localized in HERS cells or the epithelial cell rests of Malassez, which were clearly marked by cytokeratin 14 (Fig. 1E). In situ hybridization analysis revealed that Dsp mRNA was expressed exclusively in odontoblasts (Fig. 1F). Osteocalcin mRNA was expressed in both odontoblasts and differentiating odontoblasts (Fig. 1G). Therefore, conditional inactivation with the regulatory regions of this gene (OC-Cre) should affect only this cell layer.

caption.p: Localization and expression of β-catenin and marker molecules in the developing root of the mouse mandibular first molar at P14. (A) H&E stain. (B-G) Immunohistochemistry for Phex, ALPL, β-catenin, and cytokeratin 14. (F, G) In situ hybridization of Dsp and osteocalcin. (H) LacZ staining of the first mandibular molar of OC-Cre;R26R double-transgenic mouse at P10. β-catenin was localized in the odontoblast-lineage cells, pre-odontoblasts, differentiating odontoblasts, and differentiated odontoblasts. ALPL and Phex were localized in the differentiated odontoblasts, but ALPL was also localized in the differentiating odontoblasts. Dsp and osteocalcin were expressed in differentiated odontoblasts, but osteocalcin was also expressed in differentiating odontoblasts. The black arrow indicates HERS, the black arrowhead indicates differentiating odontoblasts, and the red arrowhead indicates epithelial rests of Malassez. AB, alveolar bone; Od, differentiated odontoblasts; dOd, differentiating odontoblasts; pOd, pre-odontoblasts; PDL, periodontal ligament. Scale bars: 50 µm (A-G), 20 µm (H).

sec.title: Lack of Tooth Roots in OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO Mice
sec.p: To determine the roles of β-catenin in odontoblast-lineage cells during root formation, we generated a conditional β-catenin gene inactivation mouse in the dental mesenchyme using the OC-Cre promoter. We confirmed that Cre recombination from the OC-Cre promoter was active in the odontoblast lineages during root formation. Strong LacZ expression was observed in the odontoblasts and differentiating odontoblasts of developing molar roots of OC-Cre;R26R double-transgenic mice at P10 (Fig. 1H, Appendix Fig. 1).

The mutant mice exhibited striking tooth phenotypes. By 4 wks of age, the incisors were completely erupted in control mice but not in mutant mice (Figs. 2A, 2B). In the mandible, the first and second molars were normally erupted in control and mutant mice, but the third molar was not erupted in mutant mice (Figs. 2C, 2D). Micro-tomography revealed enamel and dentin in the labial side of the mandibular incisor, but dentin was absent on the lingual side in mutant mice (Figs. 2E, 2F). Although crowns were observed in mutant mice, roots were not found (Figs. 2G, 2H). We confirmed these findings by observing isolated teeth and tooth sections from control and mutant mice (Figs. 2I, 2J, Appendix Fig. 2).

caption.p: Tooth phenotypes in OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice at P28. Both incisors and molars in mutant mice exhibited a complete lack of root formation. (A-D) Gross appearance of incisors and mandibular molars from control and mutant mice. (E-H) Micro-tomographic view of mandibles from control and mutant mice. (I-J) Stereoscopic appearance of the isolated mandibular first molar and incisor of control and mutant mice. White arrows indicate incisors. M1, first molar; M2, second molar; M3, third molar.

sec.p: In the H&E-stained mandibular molar, sections showed that crowns were completely formed with differentiated odontoblasts and had successfully erupted into the oral cavity in both mutant and control mice (Figs. 3A-3D). However, in mutant mice, odontoblasts and dentin were absent in the cervical portion of both crowns and roots. In addition, periodontal tissues had invaded the radicular pulp, and some calcified tissues had formed between periodontal tissue and radicular pulp (Fig. 3D). We performed immunohistochemical stains to assess the molecular changes following tissue-specific β-catenin inactivation. In control mice, β-catenin was strongly localized in the odontoblasts, junctional epithelium, and periodontium (Fig. 3E, Appendix Figs. 3A, 3C). In contrast, at P28, β-catenin expression was absent in the odontoblasts of the crown and cervical area but was strongly expressed in the pulp core in mutant mice (Fig. 3I, Appendix Figs. 3B, 3D). There appeared to be stronger β-catenin expression in the pulp core of the mutant mice with increasing age.

caption.p: Lack of tooth roots in the mandibular first molars of OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice. (A-D) H&E-stained sections of the mandibular first molar in control and mutant mice at P28. (E-L) Localization of β-catenin, Phex, Dmp1, and periostin in the cervical area of the mandibular first molar at P28. (B) and (D) are enlarged from the boxes in (A) and (C), respectively. The black arrows indicate calcified tissues, the black arrowhead indicates odontoblasts, and * indicates an area devoid of odontoblasts. AB, alveolar bone; C, cementum; D, dentin; Od, odontoblasts; PDL, periodontal ligament. Scale bars: 400 µm (A, C), 100 µm (B, D, E-N).

sec.p: A marker for odontoblast differentiation, Phex, was localized in crown and root odontoblasts in control mice (Fig. 3F). In contrast, although Phex was expressed in the odontoblasts of crowns, it was lost in the cervical area, where β-catenin had disappeared, in mutant mice (Fig. 3J). Dmp1 is a marker for cementum and alveolar bone in control mice (Fig. 3G). In mutant mice, Dmp1 identified alveolar bone and calcified tissues between the periodontium and radicular pulp (Fig. 3K). Periostin was strongly localized in the periodontal tissues and periosteum of alveolar bone in control mice (Fig. 3H), but in mutant mice, periostin was extensively localized in the radicular pulp as well as in the periodontium (Fig. 3L).

sec.title: Disruption of Odontoblast Differentiation in OC-Cre; Ctnnb1CO/CO Mice during Root Formation
sec.p: Because roots failed to form in mutant mice, we compared histological differences in the developing roots of the mandibular first molar between mutant and control mice. In tooth germs of P5 control mice, the cervical loop epithelium was extended to the apical side of the crown to initiate root formation. No distinguishable differences were found in the tooth germs of mutant littermates (Figs. 4A, 4E). Apparent differences between control and mutant mice first appeared at P8 (Figs. 4B, 4C, 4F, 4G). In control mice, the cervical loop epithelium extended further down to form HERS. Odontoblasts were well-differentiated in the crown, and differentiating odontoblasts appeared in the cervix, the presumptive crown-root junction. Pre-odontoblasts were located below the differentiating odontoblasts next to HERS (Fig. 4C). In mutant mice, pulp cells were condensed, and there were no differentiating odontoblasts in the cervical area (Fig. 4G). Inner layer cells of HERS as well as pre-odontoblasts were absent just below the cervical area, but pulp cells aligned inside the two-layered HERS on the apical side.

caption.p: Disrupted odontoblast differentiation during root formation in OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice. Ablation of β-catenin in the dental mesenchyme interrupted odontoblast differentiation but led to increased cell proliferation in the cervical area. (A-H) Histological features of developing roots of mandibular first molars at P5, P8, and P10. Boxed areas of (B) and (F) are magnified in (C) and (G), respectively. (I, N) Cell proliferation assay of the developing roots of mandibular first molars at P8. In both control and mutant mice, dental mesenchymal cells were highly proliferative in the apical region around HERS (blue arrowheads). In mutant mice, dental mesenchymal cells in the cervical area were also proliferative (red arrowheads), in contrast to those of control mice (red arrowheads). (J-M, O-R) Localization of β-catenin, ALPL, Phex, and cytokeratin 14 on the distal root of the mouse mandibular first molar at P8. The dotted red line indicates presumptive borders of the crown and root, the black arrow indicates HERS, the black arrowhead indicates differentiating odontoblasts, the white arrowhead indicates odontoblasts, and * indicates a cell-free area. Am, ameloblasts; C, cementum; DF, dental follicle; Od, odontoblasts. Scale bars: 100 µm (A, B, D, E, F, H, I, N), 40 µm (C, G, J-M, O-R).

sec.p: At P10, differentiating odontoblasts and HERS moved downward following root dentin formation in control mice (Fig. 4D). Although HERS in mutant mice extended apically similarly to control littermates, no dentin was formed due to failure of odontoblast differentiation in the root region (Fig. 4H). Instead of odontoblast-lineage cells, numerous pulp cells were condensed along the inside of HERS, and a cell-free area was evident.

Because histological differences between control and mutant mice were apparent in the mandibular first molar at P8, we performed BrdU-labeling experiments and immunohistochemistry to assess cell proliferation and molecular changes following β-catenin gene inactivation in the dental mesenchyme. In control mice, BrdU-labeled cells were mainly located around HERS but were not found in the cervical area of the pulp (Fig. 4I). However, BrdU-labeled cells were located in the cervical area of the pulp and around HERS in mutant mice teeth (Fig. 4N). β-catenin was immunohistochemically localized in odontoblast-lineage cells, cells derived from dental epithelium, and the dental follicle in control mice (Fig. 4J). ALPL expression overlapped in the differentiated odontoblasts and differentiating odontoblasts, which were located in the crown and cervical area (Fig. 4K). However, ALPL was not observed in the pre-odontoblasts or cells derived from dental epithelium, except the stratum intermedium. In mutant mice, β-catenin, ALPL, and Axin2 partly co-localized in crown odontoblasts but were not found in the dental mesenchyme below the cervix (Figs. 4O, 4P, Appendix Fig. 4). In control mice, Phex was observed only in crown odontoblasts, not in differentiating odontoblasts or pre-odontoblasts (Fig. 4L). In addition, Phex was also localized only in the odontoblasts of the crown in mutant mice (Fig. 4Q). In both control and mutant mice, cells derived from dental epithelium, ameloblasts, and HERS cells were marked by cytokeratin 14 (Figs. 4M, 4R).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we investigated the functional significance of Wnt/β-catenin signaling in the dental mesenchyme during tooth root formation. OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice exhibited remarkable tooth phenotypes characterized by erupted molars lacking roots and thin incisors. This abnormality was closely associated with odontoblast differentiation.

Currently, the molecular mechanisms that regulate odontoblast differentiation for root formation are unknown. Similar to crown formation, molecular interactions between dental epithelium and mesenchyme are important for root formation. It is generally accepted that HERS is important for root formation (Thomas, 1995). It is thought to initiate odontoblast differentiation from the mesenchymal cells in the dental papilla and to determine root shape and size (Ten Cate, 1996). In the developing molars of OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice, HERS initially extended after crown morphogenesis, but odontoblast differentiation was disrupted in the cervical end of the crown. Although the outer-layer cells of HERS were normally extended apically, inner-layer HERS cells lost cellular integrity, and some disappeared. These findings indicate that odontoblast differentiation could be necessary to maintain HERS cellular integrity and that HERS could be extended without root dentin formation. Therefore, our results suggest that Wnt/β-catenin signaling in the dental mesenchyme might be essential for root formation (Appendix Fig. 5).

To date, several signaling molecules are known to be necessary for root elongation in the dental mesenchyme. Nfic, a CTF binding transcription factor, regulates odontoblast differentiation during root formation, and Nfic-knockout mice exhibit short molar roots (Steele-Perkins et al., 2003). In addition, it has been reported that Smad4 and Ptc1 are also associated with root elongation (Nakatomi et al., 2006; Gao et al., 2009). Ablation of these genes in the dental mesenchyme results in molars with short roots. Furthermore, it was recently reported that epithelial Smad4 signaling is essential for HERS elongation and is mediated by the Smad4-Shh-Nfic signaling cascade (Huang et al., 2009). Although these mouse models showed defective root formation, they developed molar roots. This is in contrast to the complete absence of roots in OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice. This finding suggests that Wnt/β-catenin signaling may play a key role in the initiation of root formation and that molecular crosstalk between Wnt/β-catenin signaling and the other pathways mentioned above may be important for root elongation.

Wnt/β-catenin signaling is involved in bone formation and maintenance. Gain- and loss-of-function β-catenin mutations in osteoblasts result in osteopetrosis and osteoporosis, respectively (Glass et al., 2005). The complementary regulation is principally controlled by osteoclast function. It is well known that osteoclast-mediated bone resorption is essential for tooth eruption (Wise and King, 2008). In fact, several animal models with osteoclast dysfunction show osteopetrotic bone formation and tooth eruption failure (Tiffee et al., 1999; Lu et al., 2009). Interestingly, these models also exhibit a lack of tooth roots. This phenotype is similar to our findings in OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice, which have osteoporotic features with tooth eruption rather than osteopetrosis with eruption failure. HERS was extended but roots did not form because of odontoblast differentiation disruption in OC-Cre;Ctnnb1CO/CO mice. Moreover, despite lacking roots, periodontal structures formed and invaded the potential space between the crown and alveolar bone. Our findings indicate that teeth could erupt without root formation. Failure of root formation in osteoclast dysfunction models might be due to the interruption of HERS extension rather than to disrupted odontoblast differentiation. Taken together, the evidence suggests that HERS extension and periodontium formation, but not root formation, are critical for tooth eruption.
The results of the present study further imply that Wnt/ β-catenin signaling in the dental mesenchyme is required to differentiate odontoblasts for root formation.

fn.p: This work was supported by National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grants, funded by the Korean government (MEST) (Nos. 2009-0085733 and 2012-0006173).
The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
